newsitem.title: UK: Oil, held hostage by Iraq, rises with US gasoline.
newsitem.headline: Oil, held hostage by Iraq, rises with US gasoline.

text.p: Oil markets, edging higher on Tuesday, remained hostage to uncertainties surrounding the timing of Iraq's return to world oil markets.
Benchmark North Sea Brent blend crude futures for September closed a modest 18 cents higher in London at $18.59 a barrel, dragged higher by a surge of demand for gasoline in the United States.

Traders were waiting for the United Nations to approve a revised Iraqi aid distribution plan to pave the way for a resumption of oil exports under the second phase of the U.N.'s oil for aid exchange with Baghdad.
Under the terms of the deal, Iraq is allowed to sell up to $2 billion of oil over 180 days in two 90-day instalments.
After exporting about 700,000 barrels per day (bpd) over six months, when the exchange started in December, Iraq was given permission for a second round starting on June 8.
But Baghdad has delayed the restart of oil exports, insisting on revisions to the way aid is distributed.
Iraq is still hoping the U.N. will allow it to make up time lost since June 8 by putting back the start.
The UN insists there is no leeway on the start date.
Iraq has not yet made clear whether it try to sell its $1 billion allotment by September 5 and forfeit some sales or adopt another course of action.
Meanwhile, prices found help from tight supplies of transport fuel in the gasoline-thirsty United States.
Traders said repairs to a gasoline making unit at Exxon's huge Baytown, Texas, refinery threatened to drain already short supply in the U.S. Gulf.
The unit was closed by a lightning strike.
Dealers were expecting the American Petroleum Institute (API) to show a one to three million barrel draw in national gasoline stocks when it releases weekly oil inventory data on Tuesday evening.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
